abstract.p: Giant aneurysm of the left atrial appendage (LAA) is a rare condition typically presenting in adulthood. This case report describes the investigations and surgical management of a giant LAA aneurysm in a neonate, emphasizing the role of echocardiography and cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging in preoperative evaluation as well as challenges in surgical repair of this defect.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: We report a newborn infant with a giant aneurysm of the left atrial appendage (LAA) producing compression and thinning of the left ventricle (LV). Preoperative echocardiographic and cardiac magnetic resonance findings are presented. Surgical repair of the aneurysm was undertaken, which resulted in reversible postoperative ischemia arising from distortion of the left circumflex coronary artery.

sec.title: Patient Summary
sec.p: The patient is a term 2.7-kg female infant delivered by spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old gravida 7, para 4 mother. A fetal ultrasound at 31 weeks showed a 3-cm-diameter echo-free cystic structure adjacent to the heart, which did not change in size on follow-up fetal studies. At birth, the baby was asymptomatic with a normal examination but developed diastolic hypotension at 1 day of age, responding to intravenous volume loading. The initial electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia with T wave inversion in the lateral leads. The chest radiograph (Figure 1) demonstrated a prominent bulge of the left heart border.

caption.p: Anteroposterior chest radiograph demonstrating enlargement of the left heart border.

sec.p: Transthoracic echocardiography after delivery (Figure 2A and B) showed a large 2.9 × 3.4 cm structure communicating with the left atrium and extending along the anterolateral aspect of the LV to the midventricular level (Supplemental Video 1). The shape was consistent with LAA morphology with pectinate muscles lining the endocardial surface. Low velocity swirling flow was present in the cavity of the structure (Supplemental Video 2). Mild mitral regurgitation was noted.

caption.p: A and B, Four-chamber and short-axis echocardiographic images showing the large echo-free structure communicating with the left atrium, (C) four-chamber steady-state free precession cardiac magnetic resonance image demonstrating the LAA aneurysm with no evidence of thrombus. D, Intraoperative image showing the large, thin-walled aneurysm of the left atrial appendage. LAA indicates left atrial appendage; LV, left ventricle; LA, left atrium; RA, right atrium; RV, right ventricle; MV, mitral valve.

sec.p: Cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging at 2 days of age (Figure 2C) confirmed a giant aneurysm of the LAA, measuring 2.5 × 4.3 cm, communicating with a normal-sized left atrium proper via a 9-mm neck. No thrombus was identified in the left atrial appendage. The LV was compressed by the LAA aneurysm with basal to mid anterior and anterolateral ventricular wall thinning and dyskinesis. Left ventricular end diastolic volume index (32 mL/m2), ejection fraction (41%), and cardiac index (1.7 L/min per m2) were decreased. Myocardial tissue characterization of the LV showed no myocardial edema on T2-weighted images and no myocardial infarction or fibrosis on late gadolinium enhancement images.

The presence of left ventricular dysfunction (Supplemental Video 3) and the risk of intracardiac thrombus prompted anticoagulation and referral for cardiac surgery. In the operating room, the LAA aneurysm was easily visible within the upper portion of the pericardium and measured 4 cm in diameter (Figure 2D). The anterior portion of the aneurysm was extremely thin walled, while the posterior wall contained atrial musculature. Bulging and thinning of the lateral basal LV was present. The aneurysm was resected, leaving an 8-mm margin adjacent to the atrioventricular groove followed by reapproximation of the aneurysm neck. While weaning from bypass, the lateral LV wall became ischemic and it appeared that the left circumflex artery was compromised by distortion arising from the aneurysm closure. The left atrial suture line was therefore taken down and a patch of bovine pericardium was used to close the base of the left atrial aneurysm. This temporarily improved the lateral LV wall perfusion, but the segment again appeared dyskinetic and ischemic on decannulation, improving with recannulation and decompression of the heart. The epicardium within the atrioventricular groove was mobilized to release any distortion of the epicardial coronary vessels, but the patient required extracorporeal life support (ECLS) because of persistent ventricular dysfunction.

Subsequent coronary angiography on ECLS showed normal coronary artery origins with elongation and anterior displacement of the circumflex artery without compression, stenosis, or torsion (Figure 3A and B). The left main, anterior descending, and right coronary arteries were normal.

caption.p: A, Right anterior oblique caudal angiogram of the left coronary artery showing a normal left anterior descending artery and a tenting of the path of the left circumflex branch. B, Left anterior oblique angiogram of the left coronary artery showing abnormal anterior deviation of the left circumflex artery.

sec.p: The LV remained dysfunctional for several days, but serial echocardiography showed gradual improvement in basal, lateral, and inferior wall motion. ECLS flow rates were gradually weaned with good ventricular ejection allowing decannulation at 7 days. The basal portion of the LV wall containing the previously dyskinetic region remained dysfunctional but occupied only a small portion of the left ventricular mass.

At six-month follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic, and echocardiography showed normal global LV ejection fraction with a small dyskinetic segment of the basal inferolateral LV. At two years of age, the patient remained asymptomatic with no history of arrhythmia or thromboembolic events. The small dyskinetic segment of the LV persisted with normal global LV ejection fraction and normal left atrial size on echocardiography.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Intrapericardial aneurysm of the left atrial appendage (LAA) is a rare condition and is believed to be a result of congenital dysplasia of the musculi pectinati. 1 This condition is typically not diagnosed until the second or third decade of life or later, when patients present with embolic stroke, angina, or palpitations. Slow flow within the aneurysm predisposes the patient to thrombosis, and supraventricular tachycardias may be attributed to the stretched atrial wall or inherent abnormalities of the atrial tissue.

A small number of LAA aneurysms have been reported in infants ranging in dimension from 30 to 60 mm. 2
–5 As in our patient, two of the four cases were detected on fetal echocardiography and confirmed at birth 4-5 ; the others were diagnosed at 3 and 18 months of age, following the investigations of a murmur and distant heart sounds, respectively. 2,3 All infants were initially asymptomatic at birth except one who demonstrated mild respiratory distress. 5

To our knowledge, no previous reports of congenital giant LAA aneurysms have discussed noninvasive imaging with cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR). In this case, preoperative CMR was valuable in the assessment of the anatomy of the aneurysm and in defining the areas of LV dysfunction, while at the same time demonstrating the absence of myocardial infarction or fibrosis, the presence of which would be associated with irreversible myocardial injury after aneurysm resection.

This case demonstrates angiographic evidence of proximal left circumflex coronary artery distortion that correlated with wall motion defects in the same coronary distribution. A previous report of LAA aneurysm repair in a neonate noted, as in this case report, that postoperative ECLS support was required, 4 which is remarkable, considering the relatively minor surgical intervention in this condition. The mechanism of LV ischemia may arise from developmental abnormalities in the myocardium due to compression by the aneurysm but is likely related to coronary distortion by the LAA aneurysm preoperatively, as well as sudden changes in heart size and shape following aneurysm resection. Unexpected coronary arterial distortion or compression may complicate surgical resection of giant LAA aneurysm in the neonate and necessitate postoperative mechanical circulatory support.
